channel.title: GUI Icon Help <3
channel.description:
If I want to use:
[code]new ImageIcon("load.gif");[/code]
Where do I put the actual load.gif image? :confused:
Thanks x x x

item.title: GUI Icon Help <3
item.dc:creator: @Goat_Spirit Goat Spirit
item.description:
@Goat_Spirit wrote:

[quote=“lawl, post:1, topic:48129”][quote author=Mr.Chris link=topic=67209.msg778240#msg778240 date=1168912287]
Ah. I feel like an idiot now!

Thanks Mopar
[/quote]
you should be thinking everyone in this thread other than mopar is an idiot, not you.
all files etc that dont use an absolute path start in the working directory (which can be obtained by System.getProperty(“user.dir”) as a string)[/quote]
No, if one does not know, does that make them an idiot?

Read full topic

item.title: GUI Icon Help <3
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

[quote=“Mr.Chris, post:3, topic:48054”]I’m creating a JToolBar, and I wanted an icon next to ‘File’ to be a folder.

So, I go to my systems java file, and add file.gif in to javax.swing?[/quote]
No, just put file.gif in the same directory as the .java file is. Plus, you’ll have a hard time goin through rt.jar

Read full topic

item.title: GUI Icon Help <3
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You put them in your working directory:

ImageIcon loadIcon = new ImageIcon(“load.gif”);

should operate the same as:

ImageIcon loadIcon = new ImageIcon("./load.gif");

And as you know, “.” is the current working directory.

Read full topic

item.title: GUI Icon Help <3
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

Nope, you can

I just don’t know where to save the images:

JButton load = new JButton("Load", loadIcon);

You need to declare the loadIcon before though.

ImageIcon loadIcon = new ImageIcon("load.gif");

Read full topic

item.title: GUI Icon Help <3
item.dc:creator: @Goat_Spirit Goat Spirit
item.description:
@Goat_Spirit wrote:

[quote=“Mr.Chris, post:3, topic:48054”]I’m creating a JToolBar, and I wanted an icon next to ‘File’ to be a folder.

So, I go to my systems java file, and add file.gif in to javax.swing?[/quote]
Next to it? I don’t think that’s possible. But you can add an image instead of it:

		JToolBar toolBar = new JToolBar();
		JButton newButton = new JButton();
		String newImage = "JTE_Images/New24.gif";
		URL newImageURL = JTE.class.getResource(newImage);
		newButton.setToolTipText("Create a new file");
		if (newImageURL != null) {
			newButton.setIcon(new ImageIcon(newImageURL, "New"));
		} else {
			newButton.setText("New");
			System.err.println("newImage not found: " + newImage);
		}
		toolBar.add(newButton);
		toolBar.setFloatable(false);
		frame.getContentPane().add(toolBar, BorderLayout.NORTH);

I took that code out of my project I am working on, it’s posted a few threads down. ;)[br][size=1]Posted on: January 15, 2007, 02:08:42 PM[/size][hr]Forgot to say, whre the JTE class part is, rename it to your class. Also change the image string to what you want.

Read full topic

item.title: GUI Icon Help <3
item.dc:creator: @Goat_Spirit Goat Spirit
item.description:
@Goat_Spirit wrote:

[quote=“Mr.Chris, post:1, topic:48054”]If I want to use:

new ImageIcon("load.gif");

Where do I put the actual load.gif image?

Thanks x x x[/quote]

Image image = new Image("image.png");

It will load it from the same directory your class is in, are you trying to get an icon in the frame title?
If so I believe the code would be:

JFrame frame = new JFrame();
frame.setImageIcon(image);
//Or:
frame.setIconImage(image);

Read full topic
